content: hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft when I first started playing D&D I did what I think most people do I
instantly obsessed over my first character creation and being a grown up
former former goth I did exactly what you'd expect I rolled up eight teeth
winged warlock of course I did super duper cliche what was wasn't hold
on here we go iris the deceiver a tiefling warlock I
think immediately after my first session that I played I decided I wanted to get
a cool miniature for this character so I set out looking for something and I had
a really hard time finding anything that was appropriate I don't know if it was
the lower amount of availability on the market at the time or simply my
inexperience in the hobby and knowing where to look but I couldn't find
anything what I did come across however was a site where you can design and get
custom printed on demand your own miniatures so I designed her as' on that
website but I was reluctant to order him because I was really new to the Hobby I
only played like one or two games and I didn't know if I wanted to invest in a
custom mini for something that I might not like next week I delayed my purchase
a few more sessions maybe second or third and Aris died well actually I
don't know if Earth died or another party member died that memories a bit
foggy but somebody died and the circumstances were not great and it
caused my first big table play group fight and it basically resulted in that
campaign coming to a close but not playing D&D we were all hooked fast
forward a few years later hero 4 reaches out to me and asked me to do a
video about their mini printing services and I thought you know what this is the
perfect opportunity to give earth the deceiver another shot at life the first
thing I did was jump on the computer to start designing a model turned out when
I logged in my original design from several years ago was still there but I
decided it would be a lot more fun to make an updated version I figured the
interface and options had come a long way in the last four to five years since
I first tried it the interface is really easy to use and certainly doesn't
require any special computer or design skills I'm pretty sure basically anyone
can create a cool character in it thankfully it's open for anyone to play
with and try out so you can just jump on and try it out if you want there's no
need to actually purchase anything you can just play around with it there's a
ton of options and almost every aspect of the model is customizable well you
can quickly come up with something I did spend almost half an hour just messing
around and testing out all the various options because there was so much to
play with and I kind of wanted to see it all I did find myself wanting certain
things that weren't there or slight variations of things but I think this is
to be expected you can't realistically expect them to have every possible
option programmed in and available but they're pretty close to having all the
bases covered overall the system works really well and
adding and taking things off was easy I didn't experience any glitches with the
interface at all but there were a few times when certain options clashed with
each other and a bit of a funny way causing parts of the model to kind of
like peek through things like clothing or facial hair that didn't happen very
much and it was really easy to remedy just by adjusting things like size or
position one of the coolest parts of the system is that there's an incredible
amount of control over the figures pose there are a bunch of great presets but
you can then refine those to your liking it's really neat seeing all of the
options you've chosen like clothing and weapons and stuff change to fit the pose
of the model as you try different ones when you design
there is an option to add a base and they have several to choose from you can
also order them without a base and just on a slot so that you can base them in
your own way and personally this is what I would have chosen because I like using
the same basis across different lines of models but I thought for this
demonstration it would be best to utilize and take a look at one of the
integrated bases if you choose a base you also have the ability to add more
items to it for a bit of extra Flair I added a little rat because the character
ID rolled up years ago actually did have a pet rat companion so this was totally
perfect once your design is complete you can save it for later or order it
there's a few options for materials you can simply pay for an STL file to
download and print it yourself or you can choose from one of the four
print-on-demand options they have two plastic versions a basic and a premium
both of which come primed and ready to paint as well as two metal versions the
steel one and the bronze these vary in price point from $20 USD to $100 USD and
I wanted to be able to compare the different versions with the same model
so I ordered the plastic premium plastic and steel I did not end up ordering one
of the bronze ones as they were the most expensive and I really didn't think this
would be the option the average gamer or viewer would be after and I think
they're totally overkill for tabletop gaming but if you want the premium
premium deluxe option it is there the shipping prices are set by country and
seem to be flat rate and the shipping times depend on your location and the
materials you choose because I'm in Canada and because I chose a steel
option on my order it took a little bit longer than say just ordering a basic
plastic model ship to the USA would but even though I ordered during the holiday
season the model shipped almost a full week before the estimated ship date that
I was given on my order and arrived in about two weeks which I thought was
really impressive for print-on-demand to another country during December once
they arrived I opened them up to compare
when comparing the basic and premium plastic something sort of funny happened
in my head I reversed them I thought the black was the basic and the gray the
premium it'd been like two weeks since I made the order and I kind of mixed up
the colors in my head the interesting thing is that when comparing them I saw
very minimal difference in quality so this mix-up wasn't instantly obvious the
basic true basic the the gray one was more rigid than the premium I think this
would make it a little bit more brittle but honestly both held up just fine to
several drop tests so I'd consider both more than durable enough for tabletop
gaming both came primed but with different colors and I actually prefer
the basic gray primer more than the premium black one because it's more of a
flat primer and I find that easier to paint the black premium plastic version
was printed at a much higher resolution according to their website and based on
the support scars on the bottom the two were likely printed at different
orientations and maybe on even different machines to be honest though I couldn't
see much of a difference in detail or layer line amount between the two in
fact it was the premium plastic one that had some support scars left on the model
that I needed to clean up wasn't a big deal but it was interesting considering
the cleanup job on the basic plastic was perfect this process is almost certainly
done manually in their production though so I would expect a variation from model
to model in terms of support cleanup quality either way if there are some
little dots left from supports it's a very easy and simple thing to clean up
and it's actually way less work then same old line cleanup or gap filling on
a model you might buy from a store as for the steel model I'm not sure how to
feel its steel printed which is infused with a bronze composition it's pretty
crazy printing technology that I don't fully understand
but it's pretty neat this results in a very durable model but at the cost of
detail the entire thing is heavily textured which would make it by far the
worst option of the three for painting now the bronze one that I didn't order
does not suffer from this texture problem and they appear to be perfectly
smooth and really quite beautiful for gaming purposes I'm not sure the added
cost and durability of the steel model makes sense over the cheaper more
detailed plastic options this would make for a great gift though or display piece
to honor a favorite character from a past game maybe a beloved character in
your group suffers a heroic death and you guys want to make a nice memorial
gift for the player this would be a pretty cool thing to give them I did
find it a bit difficult to compare the two plastics that were primed in
different colors so I decided to resprayed the black one gray so I could
take a closer look during this process I noticed that there are even more support
zips that needed to be cleaned up on the base that I had missed earlier comparing
the two while they were of a similar color didn't really show any more
obvious or big differences in detail or print quality there were minimal
differences but I can't say that one was better or worse the biggest difference
is definitely the flexibility of the resin used I actually like the stiffer
plastic of the basic model better but the flexibility of the other one would
certainly make it more durable long-term being thrown in something like a bag or
dropped on the floor a lot of times of course I have to see how one of these
looked painted up and I opted to paint the basic plastic one as in theory it
should be the least forgiving and I wanted to show you guys what the
cheapest option looked like as usual I need to say it I'm not the best mini
painter I paint to an adequate table top quality which I actually think is on par
with what a lot of my viewers strive for I don't use super fancy brushes just
disposable synthetic ones with haggard and bent tips and I fight with my
essential tremor in my hands every step of the way but I get through it I pay
my miniatures with a very rudimentary and uncomplicated system it starts by
blocking out all the main colors
when doing things like detail lines my shaky hands and bad brushes simply can't
handle it so I found a great workaround when dealing with metallics gel pens I
found that they are far easier for me to control and use to make straight small
lines surely a skilled painter with steady hands will be better with a brush
but this helps me personally get the job done and hopefully this tip helps some
of you stage 2 of my simple paint jobs is using small amounts of washes to
create some simple shadows and blend the areas where different colors meet the
trick here is to not put on too much and take the time to remove any excess that
might pull up in low areas using a damp brush after the wash the third stage is
coming back in and adding some highlights for most colors I will do
this in two stages first I'll use the same color I used for the base coats to
hit some of the highest edges then I will do the same thing again but more
minimally with the same color mixed with a bit of white or light gray I rarely
get into attempting complicated wet blending or anything like that usually I
wait for the figure to be fully painted before decorating the base or in this
case painting it
I did have to pull out one cheeky trick albeit a pretty lazy one that looks far
better than it deserves based on effort to create some object source lighting
from the magic flame in his hand I used an airbrush to apply some very diluted
neon green ink to the model from the direction that the light would come this
is as easy as it gets for a fast bit of extra flair the last stage is always to
clean up the base rim with a clean coat of fresh flat black paint before sealing
the model with matte varnish so what is my final thought about hero forge minis
I think the idea of custom print on demand miniatures with tons of options
is obviously super cool and I love that this service exists I think both levels
of plastic quality are really good and I gotta say the basic plastic at the lower
price point gives the rest a run for their money
it's more than maybe worth spending for a single plastic mini in some cases but
at the same time there are so many more expensive minis out there on the market
that aren't custom this certainly isn't a great outlet for a DM to build a huge
library of hundreds of minis but I think it's a pretty fantastic way for players
to get their hands on the perfect mini to represent a character that they love
playing these make for excellent gifts and serve as a great way to memorialize
favorite characters really it depends on whether or not this service suits your
needs do you need a custom mini if you do I think hero forge is a perfect
option and I'm really glad that Aris finally got another shot at life so what
do you guys think I'm sure a lot of you out there have already used hero forge
so if you have I encourage you to go in the comments section and let others know
about your experience I hope that you enjoyed this video if you did hit the
like button let me know even if you're not interested in the service I hope
that maybe you gained some knowledge about miniature painting from somebody
who actually really struggles with it and on that struggle I do actually want
to take a moment to talk about shaky hands I kind of actually downplay how
bad shakez really are it's a big struggle
painting minis is so hard I've tried everything a lot of people recommend
things like putting elbows on the table putting their hands together and
painting this way I find that this is not enough for me sometimes when my
shakes are really bad this is my tip to you if you also struggle I have found
that the best way for me to paint minis with the shapes is to actually lean back
in my chair put my hands on my chest and hold the mini and paint it like this
it's kind of an awkward position to paint and it's certainly an awkward one
to film which is why I avoid it a fair bit but it does help so maybe it will
help you you want to pick up any tools or supplies to set yourself off on your
own Hobby journey miniature paint airbrush for example you can check out
black magic craft dot CA there I have my central equipment page where I explain
and list and link to all of the things that I use regularly for my own hobby
needs also if you really enjoy this channel in the videos I make and you
want to help me keep making them by supporting the channel and maybe you
just want to join a group of really cool like-minded individuals in the black
magic crafts fellowship you can do so by supporting the channel on patreon it's a
great way to help me keep doing what I'm doing and invest my time into making
these videos really appreciate those of you who have helped along the way that's
it for this one guys it's time to put her back on the shelf his character
sheet in the box and his mini can now live on to fulfill his destiny he'll
probably end up being a bad guy in the game
ah
